trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows

trans-unit.source: Install and configure the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows to manage Azure Services
trans-unit.target: Install and configure the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows to manage Azure Services

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI provides a set of open source, cross-platform commands for working with the Azure Platform.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI provides a set of open source, cross-platform commands for working with the Azure Platform.

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI provides much of the same functionality found in the Azure Management Portal, such as the ability to manage websites, virtual machines, mobile services, SQL Database and other services provided by the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI provides much of the same functionality found in the Azure Management Portal, such as the ability to manage websites, virtual machines, mobile services, SQL Database and other services provided by the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI is written in JavaScript, and requires Node.js.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI is written in JavaScript, and requires Node.js.

trans-unit.source: It is implemented using the Azure SDK for Node.js, and released under an Apache 2.0 license.
trans-unit.target: It is implemented using the Azure SDK for Node.js, and released under an Apache 2.0 license.

trans-unit.source: The project repository is located at <linkText>https://github.com/azure/azure-xplat-cli</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The project repository is located at <linkText>https://github.com/azure/azure-xplat-cli</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This document describes how to install and configure the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows, as well as how to use it to perform basic tasks with the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: This document describes how to install and configure the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows, as well as how to use it to perform basic tasks with the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: To learn the installation steps for the Azure CLI, read the <linkText>Install the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title> page.
trans-unit.target: To learn the installation steps for the Azure CLI, read the <linkText>Install the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title> page.

trans-unit.source: While some commands provided by the Azure CLI will work without an Azure subscription, most commands require a subscription.
trans-unit.target: While some commands provided by the Azure CLI will work without an Azure subscription, most commands require a subscription.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to configure the Azure CLI to work with your subscription, visit <linkText>Connect to an Azure subscription from the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to configure the Azure CLI to work with your subscription, visit <linkText>Connect to an Azure subscription from the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI is accessed using the azure command.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI is accessed using the azure command.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of commands available, use the azure command with no parameters.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of commands available, use the azure command with no parameters.

trans-unit.source: You should see help information similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see help information similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The top level commands listed above contain commands for working with a specific area of Azure.
trans-unit.target: The top level commands listed above contain commands for working with a specific area of Azure.

trans-unit.source: For example, the azure account command contains commands that relate to your Azure subscription, such as the download and import settings used previously.
trans-unit.target: For example, the azure account command contains commands that relate to your Azure subscription, such as the download and import settings used previously.

trans-unit.source: See [Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows] for details on the available commands and options.
trans-unit.target: See [Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows] for details on the available commands and options.

trans-unit.source: Most commands are formatted as azure [parameters] and perform an operation on a service or object such as your account configuration. Other commands provide sub-commands and follow the format azure [parameters]. The following are example commands that work with your account configuration:
trans-unit.target: Most commands are formatted as azure [parameters] and perform an operation on a service or object such as your account configuration. Other commands provide sub-commands and follow the format azure [parameters]. The following are example commands that work with your account configuration:

trans-unit.source: To view subscriptions that you have imported, use:
trans-unit.target: To view subscriptions that you have imported, use:

trans-unit.source: If you have imported subscriptions, use the following to set one as default:
trans-unit.target: If you have imported subscriptions, use the following to set one as default:

trans-unit.source: The --help or -h parameter can be used to view help for specific commands.
trans-unit.target: The --help or -h parameter can be used to view help for specific commands.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, the azure help [command] [options] format can also be used to return the same information.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, the azure help [command] [options] format can also be used to return the same information.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following commands all return the same information:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following commands all return the same information:

trans-unit.source: When in doubt about the parameters needed by a command, refer to help using --help, -h or azure help [command].
trans-unit.target: When in doubt about the parameters needed by a command, refer to help using --help, -h or azure help [command].

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI allows you to perform management operations on individual resources, which are user-managed entities such as a database server, database, or website.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI allows you to perform management operations on individual resources, which are user-managed entities such as a database server, database, or website.

trans-unit.source: This is the default mode of operation for the Azure CLI, and is referred to as Azure Service Management.
trans-unit.target: This is the default mode of operation for the Azure CLI, and is referred to as Azure Service Management.

trans-unit.source: However, when you have a complex solution that consists of multiple resources, it is useful to be able to manage the entire solution as a single unit.
trans-unit.target: However, when you have a complex solution that consists of multiple resources, it is useful to be able to manage the entire solution as a single unit.

trans-unit.source: To support managing a group of resources as a single logical unit, or resource group, we have introduced a preview of the Resource Manager as a new way of managing Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: To support managing a group of resources as a single logical unit, or resource group, we have introduced a preview of the Resource Manager as a new way of managing Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Manager is currently in preview, and does not provide the same level of management capabilities as Azure Service Management.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Manager is currently in preview, and does not provide the same level of management capabilities as Azure Service Management.

trans-unit.source: To support the new Resource Manager, the Azure CLI allows you to switch between these management 'modes' using the azure config mode command.
trans-unit.target: To support the new Resource Manager, the Azure CLI allows you to switch between these management 'modes' using the azure config mode command.

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI defaults to Azure Service Management mode.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI defaults to Azure Service Management mode.

trans-unit.source: To switch to Resource Manager mode, use the following to enable command:
trans-unit.target: To switch to Resource Manager mode, use the following to enable command:

trans-unit.source: To change back to Azure service management mode, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: To change back to Azure service management mode, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: The Resource Manager mode and Azure Service Management mode are mutually exclusive.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Manager mode and Azure Service Management mode are mutually exclusive.

trans-unit.source: That is, resources created in one mode cannot be managed from the other mode.
trans-unit.target: That is, resources created in one mode cannot be managed from the other mode.

trans-unit.source: For more information on working with the Resource Manager using the Azure CLI, see <linkText>Using the Azure CLI with the Resource Manager[cliarm]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on working with the Resource Manager using the Azure CLI, see <linkText>Using the Azure CLI with the Resource Manager[cliarm]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI allows you to easily manage Azure services.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI allows you to easily manage Azure services.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you will learn how to use the Azure CLI to manage an Azure Website.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you will learn how to use the Azure CLI to manage an Azure Website.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to create a new Azure Website.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to create a new Azure Website.

trans-unit.source: Replace mywebsite with a unique name.
trans-unit.target: Replace mywebsite with a unique name.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to specify the region that the website will be created in.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to specify the region that the website will be created in.

trans-unit.source: Select a region that is geographically near you.
trans-unit.target: Select a region that is geographically near you.

trans-unit.source: After this command completes, the website will be available at http://mywebsite.azurewebsites.net (replace mywebsite with the name you specified.)
trans-unit.target: After this command completes, the website will be available at http://mywebsite.azurewebsites.net (replace mywebsite with the name you specified.)

trans-unit.source: If you use Git for project source control, you can specify the --git parameter to create a Git repository on Azure for this website.
trans-unit.target: If you use Git for project source control, you can specify the --git parameter to create a Git repository on Azure for this website.

trans-unit.source: This will also initialize a Git repository in the directory from which the command was ran if one does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: This will also initialize a Git repository in the directory from which the command was ran if one does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: It will also create a Git remote named azure, which can be used to push deployments to the Azure Website using the git push azure master command.
trans-unit.target: It will also create a Git remote named azure, which can be used to push deployments to the Azure Website using the git push azure master command.

trans-unit.source: If you receive an error that 'site' is not an azure command, the Azure CLI is most likely in resource group mode.
trans-unit.target: If you receive an error that 'site' is not an azure command, the Azure CLI is most likely in resource group mode.

trans-unit.source: To change back to resource mode, use the azure config mode asm command.
trans-unit.target: To change back to resource mode, use the azure config mode asm command.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to list websites for your subscription:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to list websites for your subscription:

trans-unit.source: The list should contain the site created in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: The list should contain the site created in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to stop the website.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to stop the website.

trans-unit.source: Replace mywebsite with the site name.
trans-unit.target: Replace mywebsite with the site name.

trans-unit.source: After the command completes, you can refresh the browser to verify that the site has been stopped.
trans-unit.target: After the command completes, you can refresh the browser to verify that the site has been stopped.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to start the website.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to start the website.

trans-unit.source: Replace mywebsite with the site name.
trans-unit.target: Replace mywebsite with the site name.

trans-unit.source: After the command completes, you can refresh the browser to verify that the site has been started.
trans-unit.target: After the command completes, you can refresh the browser to verify that the site has been started.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to delete the website.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to delete the website.

trans-unit.source: Replace mywebsite with the site name.
trans-unit.target: Replace mywebsite with the site name.

trans-unit.source: After the command completes, use the azure site list command to verify that the website no longer exists.
trans-unit.target: After the command completes, use the azure site list command to verify that the website no longer exists.

trans-unit.source: While you can use the Azure CLI to manually issue commands, you can also create complex automation workflows by leveraging the capabilities of your command-line interpreter and other command-line utilities available on your system.
trans-unit.target: While you can use the Azure CLI to manually issue commands, you can also create complex automation workflows by leveraging the capabilities of your command-line interpreter and other command-line utilities available on your system.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command will stop all running Azure Websites:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command will stop all running Azure Websites:

trans-unit.source: This example pipes a list of websites to the grep command, which inspects each line for the string 'Running'.
trans-unit.target: This example pipes a list of websites to the grep command, which inspects each line for the string 'Running'.

trans-unit.source: Any lines that match are then piped to the awk command, which calls azure site stop and uses the second column passed to it (the running site name) as the site name to stop.
trans-unit.target: Any lines that match are then piped to the awk command, which calls azure site stop and uses the second column passed to it (the running site name) as the site name to stop.

trans-unit.source: While this demonstrates how you can chain commands together, you can also create more elaborate scripts using the scripting features provided by your command-line interpreter.
trans-unit.target: While this demonstrates how you can chain commands together, you can also create more elaborate scripts using the scripting features provided by your command-line interpreter.

trans-unit.source: Different command-line interpreters have different scripting features and syntax.
trans-unit.target: Different command-line interpreters have different scripting features and syntax.

trans-unit.source: Bash is probably the most widely used command-line interpreter for UNIX-based systems, including Linux and OS X.
trans-unit.target: Bash is probably the most widely used command-line interpreter for UNIX-based systems, including Linux and OS X.

trans-unit.source: For information on scripting with Bash, see the <linkText>Advanced Bash-Scripting Guide[advanced-bash]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on scripting with Bash, see the <linkText>Advanced Bash-Scripting Guide[advanced-bash]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more general information on scripting OS X or Linux-based systems, see <linkText>Shell script[script]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more general information on scripting OS X or Linux-based systems, see <linkText>Shell script[script]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For information on scripting Windows-based systems using batch files, see <linkText>Command-line reference A-Z[batch]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on scripting Windows-based systems using batch files, see <linkText>Command-line reference A-Z[batch]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When creating scripts, you often need to capture the output of a command and either pass this to another command or perform an operation on the output such as checking for a specific value.
trans-unit.target: When creating scripts, you often need to capture the output of a command and either pass this to another command or perform an operation on the output such as checking for a specific value.

trans-unit.source: The Azure CLI generates output to STDOUT and STDERR.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CLI generates output to STDOUT and STDERR.

trans-unit.source: Each line is prefixed by the strings info: for informational status messages, or data: for data returned about a service; however, you can instruct the Azure CLI to return more verbose information by using the --verbose or -v parameter.
trans-unit.target: Each line is prefixed by the strings info: for informational status messages, or data: for data returned about a service; however, you can instruct the Azure CLI to return more verbose information by using the --verbose or -v parameter.

trans-unit.source: This will return additional information prefixed by the string verbose:.
trans-unit.target: This will return additional information prefixed by the string verbose:.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following output is returned from the azure site list command:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following output is returned from the azure site list command:

trans-unit.source: If the --verbose or -v parameter is specified, information similar to the following is returned:
trans-unit.target: If the --verbose or -v parameter is specified, information similar to the following is returned:

trans-unit.source: Note that the verbose: information appears to be JSON formatted data.
trans-unit.target: Note that the verbose: information appears to be JSON formatted data.

trans-unit.source: You can use the --json parameter to return the information in JSON format if you are working with utilities that natively understand JSON, such as jsawk or jq.
trans-unit.target: You can use the --json parameter to return the information in JSON format if you are working with utilities that natively understand JSON, such as jsawk or jq.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The command above retrieves a list of websites as JSON, then uses jsawk to retrieve the site names, and finally uses xargs to run a site delete command for each site, passing the site name as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: The command above retrieves a list of websites as JSON, then uses jsawk to retrieve the site names, and finally uses xargs to run a site delete command for each site, passing the site name as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: The --json parameter blocks the generation of status or data information (strings prefixed by info: and data:).
trans-unit.target: The --json parameter blocks the generation of status or data information (strings prefixed by info: and data:).

trans-unit.source: For example, if the --json parameter is used with the azure site create, no output is returned as this command does not return any data other than info:.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the --json parameter is used with the azure site create, no output is returned as this command does not return any data other than info:.

trans-unit.source: While the Azure CLI does log error information to STDERR, additional information on errors may also be logged to an azure.err file in the directory that the script was ran from.
trans-unit.target: While the Azure CLI does log error information to STDERR, additional information on errors may also be logged to an azure.err file in the directory that the script was ran from.

trans-unit.source: If information is logged to this file, the following will be written to STDOUT:
trans-unit.target: If information is logged to this file, the following will be written to STDOUT:

trans-unit.source: Some of the Azure CLI commands do not return a non-zero exit status if required parameters are missing.
trans-unit.target: Some of the Azure CLI commands do not return a non-zero exit status if required parameters are missing.

trans-unit.source: Instead, they will prompt for user input.
trans-unit.target: Instead, they will prompt for user input.

trans-unit.source: For example, when using the azure site create command to create a new website, if no site name or --location parameter are specified you will be prompted to supply these values.
trans-unit.target: For example, when using the azure site create command to create a new website, if no site name or --location parameter are specified you will be prompted to supply these values.

trans-unit.source: If you are writing a script that relies on the exit status, please verify that the Azure CLI commands you are using do not prompt for user input.
trans-unit.target: If you are writing a script that relies on the exit status, please verify that the Azure CLI commands you are using do not prompt for user input.
